Explore-Heavy._description: Explore-Heavy. Big population and long runs with high mutation favor broad discovery over fast convergence. Expect slower wall-clock times, many diverse "good enough" pockets, and higher variance between runs—use when you’re unsure of the right search space or suspect multiple local optima.

Balanced Default._description: Balanced Default. Middle-of-the-road population, crossover, and annealed mutation give steady progress without overfitting pressure. Good first pass for most assets; typically finds solid performers while keeping compute and result variance reasonable.

Exploit-Anneal._description: Exploit-Anneal. Strong selection and gradually shrinking mutations push the population to refine what’s working. Converges faster and tends to polish a single basin of attraction—great after Explore-Heavy, but can miss far-off alternatives.

Quick Smoke Test._description: Quick Smoke Test. Tiny population, few generations, and high mutation are meant for wiring checks and rough sensitivity passes. Results are noisy and not production-worthy, but you’ll quickly surface broken constraints, bad bounds, or brittle metrics.

Deterministic Repro._description: Deterministic Repro. Fixed seed, stable shuffling, and conservative mutation emphasize repeatability. Ideal for audits, regression tests, and side-by-side comparisons; trades off some breadth and ultimate peak performance for consistency.

Narrow Donchian._description: Narrow Donchian. Tight ranges around classic breakout/exit lookbacks and ATR multiples concentrate search where ATR trend systems historically work. Faster convergence and cleaner attribution, but may miss regime-specific edge outside the classics.

Wide Swing-Trend._description: Wide Swing-Trend. Very broad windows for lookbacks, stops, and targets let the EA discover both fast swing and slow trend behaviors. Best when instruments differ wildly; requires more generations and stronger regularization/penalties to avoid overfitting.

Active-Tight Risk._description: Active-Tight Risk. Shorter lookbacks, lower ATR stops/TPs, and limited holding periods bias toward more trades and tighter control of losses. Suits mean-reverting or high-liquidity names; vulnerable to chop if slippage/costs aren’t modeled well.

Ride-The-Trend._description: Ride-The-Trend. Longer lookbacks and higher ATR multiples aim to capture extended runs with fewer trades. Works in persistent trends and during strong regimes; drawdowns can be larger and entries sparser.

TP-Light, Exit-Led._description: TP-Light, Exit-Led. De-emphasizes fixed take-profit and leans on exits/holding logic (or trailing) to ride moves. Useful when momentum legs vary in length; requires robust exit logic to avoid giving back gains.

Shallow Pullbacks._description: Shallow Pullbacks. Looks for mild, frequent dips in established uptrends with permissive RSI and short cooldowns. Increases trade count and capture of quick mean-reversions, but can over-trade in choppy markets.

Deep Corrections Only._description: Deep Corrections Only. Demands large ATR drawdowns, strict RSI, confirmation, and longer cooldowns. Entries are rare and higher quality; better during panicy selloffs and early recoveries, but may miss V-shaped bounces.

RSI-Gated Weakness._description: RSI-Gated Weakness. Uses RSI as the primary gate with moderate ATR distance and confirmation. Balances selectivity and frequency; good when “oversold within uptrend” is a reliable signal for your universe.

V-Reversal Hunter._description: V-Reversal Hunter. Allows larger dips but skips confirmation and keeps cooldown short to catch sharp snaps. Maximizes responsiveness at the cost of more false starts—works best on highly liquid, news-driven names.

Trend-First._description: Trend-First. Requires a strong long-term trend before any dip logic can fire, with moderate dip severity and confirmation. Reduces whipsaws markedly and pairs well with a breakout core; fewer total trades.

Classic ATR Breakout._description: Classic ATR Breakout. Canonical breakout/exit lengths with ~2–3×ATR risk/targets produce a clean momentum baseline. Easy to interpret, broadly applicable, and a solid yardstick for improvements.

Trend-Filtered ATR._description: Trend-Filtered ATR. Adds long-horizon MAs and slope checks to trade only with the prevailing trend. Typically lowers turnover and drawdowns while sacrificing some upside in range-bound markets.

Tight-Stop Scalper._description: Tight-Stop Scalper. Shorter lookbacks and smaller ATR multiples aim for many quick, low-variance wins. Sensitive to costs and slippage; shines on highly liquid tickers with frequent small swings.

Loose-Stop Trend Rider._description: Loose-Stop Trend Rider. Longer horizons and bigger ATR bands give trades room to breathe and compound. Fewer signals, longer holding periods, and higher single-trade variance—best in strong directional regimes.

Capital-Conservative._description: Capital-Conservative. Uses moderate ATR settings, trend filters, and smaller risk per trade with cost assumptions turned up. Prioritizes durability and smoother equity curves over headline returns; ideal for portfolio cores or high-risk universes.
